@trigger_snowflakes think...they don’t think they raped someone when they repeatedly said no, then eventually said yes. 
We asked “how many of you have cat called a woman or made advances to her in that time period “ they all raised they hands. We asked the woman “how many of you have been cat called and and or had sexual advancements towards them” they all raised they hands. we again asked “how many of you ladies have had men or women tell them that they need to keep silent about their encounters” they all raised their hands. Sorry, all but 42. So 678. We asked “how many ladies have been told that since they are women, they can’t amount to anything, or a man is better than them” again, all of them raised their hands. We asked the men “have you made jokes or if they truly believe men are superior to woman” about 327 men raised their hands. This is what the company is saying. And it’s sad a razor company has to say “stop being assholes to woman”

@trigger_snowflakes let me put it this way. I’ve been to two high schools. For a grant total of 1,400 all together (being generous, that and not including my first high school, which had roughly 1,000 3yrs ago, I’d say it’s up to 1,300 but I’ll just keep it at which it was when we tested it) roughly 55% were females and 45% was males. Let’s just say 50/50 for simpler math. So that is obviously 700 males and females. Well we did a study. Out of 700 females who have been sexually assaulted or raped (this includes  unwanted advancements that are obviously included in sexual harassment) 623 young ladies said that this happened to them. Not including the ones who were too scared to admit. Which we later added over 40, because of this reason. Bringing the total to a horrible 663 young ladies. We asked the men “have they ever been raped, or sexually harassed” 3 came forward. And they were already open about it. No one came forward in secrecy. We asked them, “has anyone been falsely accused of rape or sexual harassment?” One did, but it turned out, with evidence through court, he was lying. We ask “how many of you have been asked a girl multiple times until she said yes to have any sexual interactions” 562 raised they hands. A staggering 96 more, came forward, and admitted they did, but felt horrible. But wait. It gets worse

@feminist409 I respect your opinion also.
I guess the whole point of debate is to put across your views and also listen to others opposing views.
It seems there are different ways to interpret the advert and the entire threads I’ve seen appear to be a mix of both.
Regardless of our different opinions on how this was executed, I think it’s safe to say everybody opposes bullying, harassment and violence. The main disagreement seems to be whether it’s the majority or the minority and whether it’s mostly men or not.

@leanneyhunter I respect your personal opinion, but I think the commercial brought forward forgotten problems in a good way. The tv portion I saw, was a man sexually harassing a women, which is not ok, it showed a man making a horrible remark to a women in a bikini, then another man standing up for her. Play fighting is pushing, or rolling on the ground, those kids were hitting each other, almost punching, which is not play fighting. I took the men doing good things in the opposite way, I thought it showed that most men are doing good things, and everyone needs to work together to stop the bad ones. I do believe they should have shown that women do bad things in the commercial also, but their main demographic is men

@feminist409 Maybe that’s not how you interpreted it but obviously many others have or there wouldn’t be such a fuss.

For example, I feel the males it shows looking at women in bikinis on tv is fine, it’s not anything to do with toxic masculinity, the reason I feel this way is because there are plenty of females who like to look at them too!

Play fighting is fine! If it’s not real fighting, girls do this too. That’s just another stereotypical scene which was unnecessary.

The advert also made reference to how some men are already acting the way they should.... Rather than saying only some men are good, (Implying the majority are bad), they should say the opposite, only some men are bad (and acknowledge most are decent human beings) that is what has got people’s backs up the most.

Then they stereotyped men as being big dumb oafs stood behind barbecues, that’s not okay either.

A lot of feminists seem to think if we don’t like the advert then we are all for bad behaviour, when actually we don’t like poor antics either but we dislike the way men have been portrayed and masculinity as a whole. Rather than just the negative behaviours which actually apply to both sexes.
@feminist409 well I’m not oppressed. I know women in third world countries are but all I see in modern day society here is men getting a poor deal.

I personally feel it is a disgusting and vile commercial and has wasted the opportunity to really get an important message across.
@leanneyhunter the add is not saying they are bad, it is saying there is problems with some men, and all need to be aware to fix them.

@marqusloqus no, women cause a lot of problems, we don’t support each other, we abuse people, we don’t get harsh sentencing, we expect men to do specific things, we can be prejudice towards people, etc. I hope they make a commercial about women
